com.elvenware.codebox
Class GuiBox

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.elvenware.codebox.GuiBox
public final class GuiBox
extends java.lang.Object

Title: GuiBox.java

Description: Ways to launch dialogs.

You normally decide whether or not a dialog is modal when you construct it. You can put some constants and a declaration at the top of a modal dialog:

   public static final int STATE_CANCEL = 0;
   public static final int STATE_OK = 1;
   public int state;

Then write code to close the dialog:

   void jButtonCancel_actionPerformed(ActionEvent e)
  {
   state = STATE_CANCEL;
   this.dispose();
 }

 void jButtonOk_actionPerformed(ActionEvent e)
 {
   state = STATE_OK;
   this.dispose();
 }

Then write some code to call the dialog:

  TestDialog testDialog = new TestDialog(this, "Test Dialog", true);
  GuiBox.showDialog(this, testDialog);
  if (testDialog.state == TestDialog.STATE_CANCEL)
  {
    JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(this, "Canceled");
  }
  else
  {
    JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(this, "Ok");
  }

Company: Elvenware

Method Detail

showDialog

public static void showDialog(java.awt.Component owner,
                              javax.swing.JDialog dlg,
                              boolean modal)
Usually you set the modal feature of a dialog when you construct it. However, you can also set it it with setModal function shown here. So if you have a dialog that was not constructed as modal, you can make it modal by passing it to this method.

Parameters:
owner - Usually a JFrame or JDialog.
dlg - The dialog you want to show.
modal - Whether or not you want it to be modal.

showDialog

public static void showDialog(java.awt.Component owner,
                              javax.swing.JDialog dlg)
Code for centering and launching a JDialog. The dialog will be made about 3/4 the size its owner, and will appear in the center of its owner.

Parameters:
owner - The owner of the dialog, usually a JFrame
dlg - The dialog to launch

showDialogPreferredSize

public static void showDialogPreferredSize(java.awt.Component owner,
                                           javax.swing.JDialog dlg)

showDialogSize

public static void showDialogSize(java.awt.Component owner,
                                  javax.swing.JDialog dlg,
                                  int width,
                                  int height)
Show a dialog by specifying its size. You normally set whether or not you want a dialog to be modal when you construct the dialog.

Parameters:
owner - Usually a JFrame or JDialog
dlg - The dialog you want to show.
width - The width of the dialog you want to show.
height - The height of the dialog you want to show.

showDialogSameSizeOwner

public static void showDialogSameSizeOwner(java.awt.Component owner,
                                           javax.swing.JDialog dlg)
Show a dialog centered over its owner and the same size as its owner. You usually define whether or not a dialog is modal when you construct it.

Parameters:
owner - The JFrame or JDialog that owns this dialog.
dlg - The dialog you want to show.
